title: A comprehensive SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19 review, Part 2: Host extracellular to systemic effects of SARS-CoV-2 infection
background: COVID-19, caused by SARS-CoV-2, has caused significant global morbidity and mortality. This review focuses on the biological effects of SARS-CoV-2 on post-acute disease in the context of tissue and organ adaptations and damage.
objective: To provide an overview of current knowledge of SARS-CoV-2 biological effects from basic biology to clinical outcomes, highlighting extracellular and circulating signals and physiological effects of viral disease.
methods: Comprehensive literature review integrating virological, animal, and clinical studies to understand mechanisms driving varied clinical diagnoses and observations.
results: SARS-CoV-2 infection causes systemic metabolic adaptations, humoral changes, cardiovascular alterations, immune dysregulation, and multi-organ damage through various mechanisms including mitochondrial dysfunction, cytokine storms, and endothelial injury.
conclusion: COVID-19 is a pleiotropic, complex condition with viral insults and cellular adaptations differing across contexts, requiring integrated understanding from cellular to organ systems for effective interventions.

core_problems: Immune system dysregulation in space analogs
key_outcomes: SARS-CoV-2 causes mitochondrial suppression and metabolic shifts
Virus induces endothelial dysfunction and cardiovascular damage
Immune dysregulation involves cytokine storms and lymphopenia
Multi-organ infection persists long-term in PASC
Non-coding RNAs play regulatory roles in infection
extracted_entities.confidence: High - based on multiple clinical studies, autopsy findings, and experimental models
gaps: Lack of human data on ACE2 expression in endocrine tissues under pathological conditions
Limited understanding of long-term cardiovascular mitochondrial adaptations
Insufficient data on SARS-CoV-2 effects on GI physiology
opportunities: Multi-system physiological monitoring for crew health
Biomarker panels for early detection of systemic dysfunction
Understanding viral persistence in isolated environments

learning_notes.note: SARS-CoV-2 infection causes significant mitochondrial dysfunction, suppressing oxidative phosphorylation and TCA cycle metabolites like citrate, fumarate, and malate, while increasing glycolysis and shunting toward pentose phosphate pathways. These metabolic shifts correlate with disease severity and represent potential biomarkers for monitoring physiological stress in confined environments.

The virus directly interacts with the renin-angiotensin system (RAS) through ACE2 receptors, causing imbalance with decreased ACE and increased ACE2, renin, angiotensin, and bradykinin. This dysregulation leads to cardiovascular symptoms and could inform monitoring of cardiovascular adaptations in spaceflight conditions.

Exosomes from SARS-CoV-2 infected patients contain viral components and immunomodulatory molecules that can stimulate inflammatory pathways in endothelial cells. Exosomes containing ACE2 can act as decoys to inhibit viral entry, suggesting potential therapeutic applications for viral protection in isolated environments.

Non-coding RNAs including miRNAs, lncRNAs, and circRNAs play significant regulatory roles in SARS-CoV-2 infection. Circulating miRNA hsa-miR-2392 drives mitochondrial gene suppression and inflammation, while specific lncRNAs correlate with viral loads and immune responses, offering diagnostic potential.

Cardiovascular adaptations include direct viral infection of endothelial cells, micro/macrovascular thrombosis, and suppression of cardiac functional markers. Autopsy studies show SARS-CoV-2 presence in myocardial tissue with decreased expression of TNNI3, TNNT2, and other cardiac markers despite no histological changes.

Immune dysregulation involves both innate and adaptive systems, with neutrophil activation, NETosis, type I interferon signaling disruption, and lymphopenia. Severe COVID-19 shows elevated IL-6, IL-8, TNF-α with increased NF-κB activity, while airway inflammation shows different cytokine patterns than systemic circulation.

Post-acute sequelae (PASC/long COVID) involves persistent viral presence across multiple organs including brain tissue for up to seven months, chronic fatigue potentially from mitochondrial dysfunction, elevated type I/III interferons, activated innate immune cells, and decreased naive T and B cells, highlighting long-term health risks relevant to extended missions.
